content: There is a definition of TM2ComputableInPolyTime for TM2. Also, there is a proof that TM0, TM1, TM2 emulate each other and hence they are computationally equivalent. However, a proof showing a polynomial equivalence in a sense they emulate each other in polynomial number of steps wrt the input size seem missing. For instance showing 3-neighborhhod Cellular automaton computation can be mutually emulated by TM in polynomial time would be easier for TM0 than for TM2. But the polynomial computability for TM0 may not be defined. Likely I am missing something. Is there a proof of polynomial equivalence between these TMs?
It seems plausible that this is missing; this part of the library doesn't see a lot of development
It should be reasonably straightforward to state what "computes in polynomial time" means for TM0, TM1, TM2 because they all use the same interface of a state and step function
The simulations are also written to be polynomial reductions, but this is not proved (at the time the definition did not exist)
I see, thank you very much for your insight.
Roman Bacik has marked this topic as resolved.
